info.document:
Hurricane Jose may threaten New York City and other areas of the East Coast by next week, according to the National Hurricane Centre.

The storm, about 775km south-southeast of Cape Hatteras, North Carolina, strengthened into a Category 1 hurricane late on Friday as it churned through the Atlantic Ocean. Jose's path could put it near New Jersey and New York by Wednesday morning, although it may weaken to a tropical storm again by then, the centre said.

More World News Videos Previous slide Next slide Florida Keys residents assess Irma ... Florida Keys residents assess Irma devastation

Some Florida residents were allowed to return to their shuttered homes and several airports re-opened on Tuesday, after Hurricane Irma prompted the evacuation of 6.5 million people.

Up Next US highlights military options on North Korea US highlights military options on North ... US highlights military options on North Korea

Hours after Pyongyang shot yet another missile over Japan into the Pacific Ocean, the US responded by highlighting their military options.

Up Next St. Louis protests over judge ruling St. Louis protests over judge ruling St. Louis protests over judge ruling

Hundreds of protesters marched through city streets after a judge found St. Louis police officer Jason Stockley not guilty of first-degree murder in the 2011 death of 24-year-old Anthony Lamar Smith.

Up Next Rohingya refugees now in the hundreds of thousands Rohingya refugees now in the hundreds of ... Rohingya refugees now in the hundreds of thousands

A dire humanitarian situation is unfolding with the number fleeing violence in Myanmar rises above a quarter-of-a-million, as refugee camps in Bangladesh are increasingly overcrowded.

Up Next London tube blast: 'A proper human crush' London tube blast: 'A proper human crush' London tube blast: 'A proper human crush'

Witnesses recount scenes of terror after an improvised bomb detonated on a commuter train at Parsons Green underground station in London.

Up Next White House calls ESPN 'hypocritical' White House calls ESPN 'hypocritical' White House calls ESPN 'hypocritical'

Press Secretary Sarah Sanders says ESPN is hypocritical for not firing its anchor Jemele Hill after she called President Donald Trump a white supremacist.

Up Next Trump calls for 'tougher' action after London blast Trump calls for 'tougher' action after ... Trump calls for 'tougher' action after London blast

'We have to be tougher, smarter', US President Donald Trump says after a home-made bomb on a London train injures at least 29 people.

Up Next 'Further attack may be imminent': Theresa May 'Further attack may be imminent': Theresa ... 'Further attack may be imminent': Theresa May

Britain raises its national security threat level from severe to critical, meaning an attack is expected, after a bomb on a London commuter train injured 29 people.

More videos Florida Keys residents assess Irma devastation

Some Florida residents were allowed to return to their shuttered homes and several airports re-opened on Tuesday, after Hurricane Irma prompted the evacuation of 6.5 million people.

The storm may add to an already devastating 2017 Atlantic hurricane season, coming just after Hurricane Harvey inundated Texas and Hurricane Irma raked Florida's west coast, leaving dozens of people dead and upending energy and agriculture markets.

In 2012, Superstorm Sandy created about $70 billion of damage after hitting the New York metropolitan region.

As of 11am New York time, Jose was moving northwest at 20kmh. Little change in strength is forecast during the next two days, the centre said. Tropical storm watches could be issued for parts of the US coast, from North Carolina to New England, over the next day or two, according to the advisory, the 45th so far on the long-lived weather system.

If it continues toward New York City, Jose could disrupt vessels carrying crude oil, petrochemicals and refined products along the Atlantic seaboard, "particularly those making deliveries to New York Harbour," Shunondo Basu, a Bloomberg New Energy Finance meteorologist and natural gas analyst in New York, said on Friday.

Bloomberg
